thread.title: Why Indiegogo believes the crowd is better than a bank
thread.title_full: Why Indiegogo believes the crowd is better than a bank - MarketWatch

author: By     Caitlin Huston
title: Why Indiegogo believes the crowd is better than a bank
text:
While federal agencies debate the rules and regulations of who can invest in private companies through crowdfunding, Indiegogo wants to make the process even more open and simple.
“We fundamentally believe that everybody deserves one opportunity to see whether or not the world or the crowd wants to fund them,” said Indiegogo Chief Executive Slava Rubin,
An early entrant to the crowdfunding scene, the Indiegogo model allows anyone to start a campaign, with the idea that it is up to the crowd, not Indiegogo, to judge the merit of a project or business venture. Unlike competitors such as Kickstarter, Indiegogo does not vet proposed projects.
This viewpoint sets the company apart in the space just as the Securities and Exchange Commission gradually rolls out regulations for the Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act, including a provision to allow startups raise up to $50 million from non-accredited investors . These regulations are aimed at equity crowdfunding – a space Indiegogo is considering – with the goal of allowing average individuals to safely invest in private companies.
Based in San Francisco,the site was recently host to global campaigns, such as the Greek Bailout campaign, relief efforts after Nepal’s earthquake, as well as a new way to harvest honey, among others.
Rubin, then a strategy consultant, and his co-founders, Danae Ringelmann and Eric Schell, came up with the idea for the company after Ringelmann, an investment banker, said she wanted to democratize finance.
After initially being discouraged by the regulations around profit-based models, the trio looked to the peer-to-peer lending offered by Prosper and the beginning of YouTube, which Rubin said was “democratizing content.” Their goal was to become a “ProspeTube” platform.
Rubin said he and the founders delayed taking any venture capital funding, choosing to run off their personal savings and wait until they had a test case to present to investors. Then the 2008 financial crisis hit, and the plan fell through.
“We got turned down by 93 VCs until 2010,” Rubin said.
Indiegogo is the first business created by any of the founders, and venture capitalists cited their inexperience, general market conditions and the new model of funding as reasons not to invest, said Rubin.
A no judgment policy “We fundamentally believe that everybody deserves one opportunity to see whether or not the world or the crowd wants to fund them.” - Slava Rubin, Indiegogo CEO. Indiegogo offers two funding models: a fixed one, where campaign creators have to meet a set goal to receive any of the funds; or a flexible one, where the creators take whatever was raised by the end of the campaign.
Starting Wednesday, Indiegogo is charging a 5% fee for campaigns that reach the set goals using either model. The money is returned to backers when fixed funding campaigns don’t reach the funding goal and the campaigns are not charged a fee by Indiegogo.
In December, the company launched a separate Indiegogo Life page for personal campaigns, that charges no fee and allows them to run indefinitely.
Indiegogo does not evaluate or measure the feasibility of campaigns before they’re posted.
